moves.9... Nb6 10. O-O-O Nbd5 11. c3 c6: Black seems to have a solid postion.
moves.12. h4: This begins a very ambitious plan to use the rook pawn to storm the kingside.
moves.12... Qa5: Black prepares an attack as well.
moves.13. Kb1 Qb6: Threatens Nc3 ! after the exchange of knights
moves.15... Qc7: Black did not fully appreciate the significance of h5.
moves.16. Nxf6+: Now begins exchanges so that the queen can move to e4
moves.16... Nxf6 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Qe4 g6: Forced--now the significance of e5 becomes clear.
moves.19. Rh2: With thoughts of doubling rooks on the h-file
moves.20. hxg6 hxg6 21. Ne5: Forcing the exchange of bishop for knight.
moves.21... f5 22. Qh4 Bxe5 23. dxe5 Qg7: Forced, but Black appears to have survived the attack. White decides to support e5 and exploit the bad bishop.
moves.24. f4 Kf7: The king appears to have escaped, and Black prepares to contest the h-file.
moves.25... Bd7: Black wants to get the bishop out to free the rook.
moves.26. gxf5: If instead 26 Bxf5?!, Ke8!. The move 26 gxf5! prepares a more subtle but deadly attack
moves.26... exf5 27. Bc4+: 27 Bc4 ! destroys Black's position. If ....Be6? Rd7!  wins the queen
moves.27... Ke8 28. e6: Black is lost. If ...BxP, the piece is lost and the king is exposed to a withering attack. If the bishop retreats, Qd8
moves.28... Rd8: The only move to hang on.
moves.29. Re2: White is concerned about the back rank, and wants to trap the black king in the center.
moves.30. exd7+: This double check finishes Black who resigns, since Kf8 (forced) is followed by QxR   .
